speaker: MR. TAYAB

text: A key product is a low-level carbon monoxide detector specifically for pilots, for aircraft application, and it's -- there's a need, a need where you're in a small volume of space or an automobile or an aircraft and there is a leak coming from somewhere, some situation is going on, and occupants, such as moms and dads and other people concerned about their health, typically purchase these products and they monitor the environment.

speaker: MR. TAYAB

text: So the definition of low level basically means one will be alarmed of carbon monoxide at a low level.  Low level is less than 70 parts per minute.  There's a demand -- a lot of people, again, as I mentioned, folks driving vehicles, flying planes and others, believe that being alarmed at 70 parts per million following the UL 2034 protocol from 60 to 240 parts per million is not adequate enough.  And there is --

text: Okay.  Now, you mentioned the Saba case, and that's listed in your list of cases as well. Can you tell me a little bit about that case?
speaker: MR. TAYAB

text: That was a situation where it was a home in Arizona, and the -- both gas burning appliances, the boiler and the furnace, were located in a small, confined cabinet.  And what was occurring was a backdraft situation where when the furnace was on and the water heater was on, it would suck in the exhaust coming out from the boiler, the hot water system, and in that situation, it was polluting and it was polluting the inhabitants of the home.

text: That modeling -- that modeling analysis was undertaken what we call based on a mass balance model.  I employed software that's readily available from the EPA to undertake that analysis, and that analysis determined what a typical carbon monoxide profile would look like in a residence over a period of time.  I believe that period of time was over a 24-hour period, if I recall correctly.

text: Why do you disagree with that statement?
speaker: MR. TAYAB

text: Simply because the origins of the definition and the use of COAF was developed early in the 20th century for that exact purpose where the impetus was on the human health aspects of occupants of an enclosed space reaching and exposed to 100 parts per million within a one-hour period. And what they did when they were developing this methodology of COAF measurements was to look at the human health aspects based on this 100 parts per million over a one-hour period that they deemed to be inappropriate, and they backward engineered the circumstances and the flu emissions to come up with a COAF that would produce in a certain volume of space, given certain assumptions, an amount of flue gas, COAF, that would then occur in the ambient up to 100 parts per million for one hour. So the point here is, the historic evolution of COAF or the origin of COAF has actual roots and impetus and motivation from a human health standpoint which, on Page 2, Paragraph 8, says the total polar opposite.

text: This statement means that the sensor, the concentration that it reads, would have an accuracy of plus minus 3 percent of its reading.  So, for example, if we are reading 100 PPM, it could be either 103 PPM or 97 PPM at its calibrated temperature. So if one is to calibrate this detector at room temperature, 70 degrees Fahrenheit, and you were taking a measurement at 70 degrees Fahrenheit, you would only be considering the plus minus 3 percent accuracy. However, if one is increasing or elevating the temperature of operation, you must add .28 percent of your reading in addition to the 3 percent, .28 percent per Fahrenheit that is elevated above the calibrated temperature. So if one again is taking a measurement at 100 degrees Fahrenheit and it has been calibrated at 70 degrees Fahrenheit, one would have to undertake a calculation.  The difference in temperature is 30. text: As I mentioned, we have a volume of space.  We have carbon monoxide in that volume of space, such as this room, but in this case, specifically, it's a flue gas situation and we know that there are combustion products in that space of volume. In that space of volume, we have excess air due to the combustion process that could be 100 percent.  It could be a thousand percent.  We determine that via an oxygen or Co2 measurement and convert that into the excess air amount, which is dilution factor of the carbon monoxide.  This occurs in a flue gas environment. So the excess air coming from the flue gas, the combustion process, is diluting the carbon monoxide as the sensor sees it.  As the carbon monoxide sensor detects it, it is reducing typically as the excess air is increased.  That is the best way to describe it.

speaker: MR. TAYAB

text: Typically, yes.  Typically, yes.  The COAF is used mostly in a combustion flue gas environment, emissions and others where one wants to extract the real concentration of the carbon monoxide. So if one is undertaking, for example, an emission measurement, one should be using COAF to determine the amount, the absolute amount of carbon monoxide emitted into a certain location coming from a flue gas environment. Similarly, if one is to inhale a pure flue gas volume of space into their lungs, one is inhaling -- one is to calculate and understand the absolute carbon monoxide concentration, not the as-measured CO signal coming from and as-measured CO sensor. One must take into account the absolute amount, and that's exactly what the COAF is meant to do.  It's been designed so that it removes the dilution factor which is coming from the excess air and providing the user or the person adopting this methodology a true, a true sense of the absolute carbon monoxide in that volume of space.

text: Well, as I was mentioning, the first value is that the emissions coming from a burner cycle turning on has typical characteristics of most combustion burners, which is a low of the peak and then coming to some steady state situation.  That's the first. The second is its sensitivity to both the air and gas intakes where we can see, as we tweak those variables just slightly, the carbon monoxide varies considerably. For example, Test Number 1 here is six gases 3.5 inch water column.  What is emitted is about the peak at about a 40-second mark is about 660 or -70 COAF. And then adjusting those variables can considerably increase the COAF emissions, as shown in multiple examples here, reaching up to 8000, for example, in Test Number 6, and Test Number 7 in the 2000s. So the value, coming back to your question, again solidifies what I have known myself when it comes to combustion and burners in general is that slight tweaks to the variables, such as gas or the air fuel ratio, which is effectively what is going on, considerably changes the emissions, the flue gas emissions being produced.
